The Buddha said:
Boundless Adornments!
This is the seal method of liberation from all written words, and all dharmas are included within it.
What is called entering?
Because of equality.
All dharmas enter into equality, yet one does not see the dharmas entering into equality, because they cannot be known or attained.
When the intrinsic nature of all dharmas is truly not discriminated, all dharmas are included within it, because they are apart from non-action and action.
Because all words and verbal actions explain the dharmas, but these two are not real.
Because of the equality of nature, all words and verbal actions are also equal.
All explanations of the dharmas are not real, this is the meaning of the true words of the dharmas.
All words and verbal actions are both non-existent, because of non-existence, there is no true explanation.
What is said to be without true words and verbal actions is the non-discriminatory phrase of all dharmas, the non-superior phrase, the non-established phrase, this profound Dharma cannot be spoken.
All dharmas are neither real nor unreal.
Why is it so?
The inherent nature of all dharmas cannot be seen or attained by explaining with words and verbal actions. All dharmas are without inherent nature.
Such dharmas are neither created nor not created, neither equal nor unequal, neither tranquil nor not tranquil, yet they also abide in tranquility and non-tranquility with regard to all dharmas.
What is called abiding is also without abiding and also without change, and it also does not abide in the dharma of non-change.
Why is it so?

Because the dharma is without abiding, it does not enter into calculation. It is not by means of calculation that one can cause the dharma to enter into calculation through the establishment of verbal teachings.
All written words and verbal actions are all unobtainable, and they do not abide in a place or in all places.
Such written words and verbal actions come from nowhere, go nowhere upon leaving, and do not abide in the middle or the extremes.

All written words and verbal actions, because of being neither action nor non-action, because of being non-effort, and because the intrinsic nature of all written words and verbal actions is empty, written words and verbal actions are also all empty.
Also, because the verbal actions of written language are empty of other-nature, other-nature is also empty.
Up to because the self and other natures are empty, the self and other natures are also empty.
Because the self and other are empty, they are then quiescent. If they are quiescent, they are then extinguished. If they are extinguished, all dharmas are then the gate of extinction.

Because of those various gates, the name of the Dharma is expounded. Whether expounding written language or expounding verbal actions, all those gates are also unobtainable, because the gates are pure and nonexistent.
Because of those various gates expounding the dharmas, within this gate one ultimately attains purity and is able to equally enter all dharmas, thus becoming disenchanted.
How does one become disenchanted?
It means the fundamental nature of craving.
The fundamental nature of craving is then pure. If it is pure, it is then ultimate. If it is ultimate, how can there be craving?
How can there be speech?
